feedback.Physical object: Excluded — The org chart is typically a visual or digital abstraction, not a tangible object itself.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Excluded — While created by humans, it has no synthetic material form.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — Its structure may echo biological hierarchies, but it is not biologically based.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — Org charts evolve over time with company structure.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — It is not a physical structure but a conceptual one.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — Its depiction is perceptible, but the chart as a system is abstract.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — Exists in printed or digital forms, but not as intrinsic material entity.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — It plays an active role in communicating hierarchy and authority.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Org charts are created to communicate organizational roles and authority.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — It does not independently generate effects.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — It is not a signal processor.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — It does not autonomously alter system states.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — It is a reference diagram, not an interface.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Included — It reflects the formal structure of a corporate or institutional system.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — It must be updated and maintained by people.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Useful but not foundational to the existence of the organization.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Represents roles, reporting lines, and institutional hierarchy.
feedback.Communicative: Excluded — While it conveys information, it is not itself a communicative agent.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Encodes relationships based on organizational rules and policies.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Included — It is a direct representation of hierarchical structure.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Excluded — It reflects roles rather than prescribes behavior.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — It does not describe itself or model model-making.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — Though subject to change over time, it does not intrinsically express time.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Excluded — It is specific to organizational context but not abstracted across contexts.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — Reflects social and cultural norms about organization and hierarchy.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Created and maintained by the institution it represents.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Included — Maps roles to people, embedding identity in structure.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Included — Conforms to HR policies and corporate governance standards.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — Used in training and orientation.
feedback.Visible: Included — Presented in public/internal documents, slide decks, and dashboards.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Varies significantly across cultures and institutions.
feedback.Widely known: Included — The concept and format of org charts are broadly recognized across industries.

encoding_notes: The corporate org chart is modeled here as a symbolic-abstract-social artifact that encodes organizational structure and roles. It is intentionally designed, embedded in institutional logic, and governed by formal rules. While visually represented, it is not a physical object, but rather a model of social architecture. The corrected code '0084B0FF' faithfully reflects the selected traits.
